Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3648496 Skew Premiums around Earnings Announcements Abstract: In this study, we examine skew premiums in equity options around earnings announcements. Earnings announcements can trigger extreme price reactions in stocks but some theoretical models suggest that anticipated price jumps should not carry a skew premium. We use the realized returns to delta-neutral risk reversals option spread positions as a proxy for the skew premiums. We find skew premiums are economically and statistically significant around earnings announcements. In particular, for firms with negative option-implied skewness, negative skew premiums double on earnings announcements. For firms with positive option-implied skewness, positive skew premiums increase about 23 percent. These results hold conditional on variance risk premiums, are associated with order imbalances in puts to calls, and are related to both systematic and idiosyncratic risks. Finally, we find that some firm reporting characteristics explain the cross-section of earnings announcements skew premiums. Numerous studies examine equity returns around earnings announcement dates (EADs) and conclude that both expected and realized returns are elevated during these periods (Ball and Kothari, 1991; Cohen et al., 2007; Savor and Wilson, 2016). These abnormal returns are generally interpreted as compensation to investors for bearing undiversifiable disclosure risk related to the information released around the earnings announcement. Other studies focus on the returns to equity options around EAs (e.g., Barth and So, 2014; Dubinsky et al., 2019) as investors are exposed to changes in future equity volatilities, in addition to changes in equity prices, around the earnings announcement (e.g., Neururer et al., 2016). This research documents significant premiums in straddle1 positions around EAs, indicative of risks related to unidirectional price movements and also to changes in volatilities that may be triggered by the information released during the earnings announcement (Dubinsky et al., 2019). We extend this literature by focusing on an alternative risk that investors bear with the earnings information release: skew risk.2 Our focus on skew risk derives from evidence in prior studies finding asymmetric equity price reactions to earnings releases; in particular, prior literature suggests that negative stock returns are more pronounced, on average, compared to positive reactions on EADs (e.g., McNichols, 1988; Acharya et al., 2011; Smith, 2021). These documented return asymmetries around EADs may also result in differential pricing of insurance contracts designed to protect against such asymmetries in the market reactions to earnings announcements. text: Asymmetric Stock Returns and Information Releases Stock market index returns display negative skewness indicating the presence of negative returns with greater probability than suggested by a symmetric distribution. This effect is both found in conditional and unconditional returns (e.g., Harvey and Siddique, 1999). In addition, index OTM put options typically have much higher IVs relative to OTM call options suggesting a high negative risk-neutral skew. In contrast, individual stocks have more positively skewed returns distributions relative to market indices (Albuquerque, 2012). Similar patterns are found in the equity option market; risk-neutral distributions for stocks are generally more positively skewed relative to the index options (Bakshi et al., 2003). However, when examining EAD returns, several authors have noted that stock returns are more negatively skewed when compared to non-EAD returns. As Smith (2021) notes, a valuation signal that is more informative when it reveals negative rather than positive news causes returns to exhibit negative return skewness. McNichols (1988) suggests that, on average, more bad news is disclosed in the mandatory reports and managers may be more likely to release good news ahead of EAs. Likewise, Miller (2002) finds firms are more likely to provide voluntary information when earnings performance is strong helping generate negatively skewed returns on EADs (also see Kothari et al., 2009). McNichols (1988) also finds that the effect is not due to small firms. Instead, she finds that the asymmetric effect of EAs on stock returns is stronger for large and medium-sized firms. Similarly, Acharya et al. (2011) suggest firms will tend to release good news in periods where there are no other public signals. However, when signals are required, firms will tend to release, on average, bad information. This again creates asymmetries in returns around information releases. There are other explanations for more negatively skewed equity returns around EADs (compared to non-EADs). If the precision of information contained in the EA is unknown then, according to the model of Epstein and Schneider (2008), investors will react more strongly to negative news relative to positive news. Investors, when confronted with ambiguous news, will treat bad news as if it has high precision. For good news, investors will treat the news as imprecise. This creates asymmetric reactions to information based on the sign of the news and leads to asymmetric return distributions. Williams (2015) presents evidence of this effect: stock returns appear more asymmetric in periods where ambiguity is likely higher. Finally, Veronesi (1999) shows that in a Bayesian model with risk-averse investors, stock prices respond more to bad news in good times and vice versa thus creating asymmetries in stock returns. Earnings Announcements and Risk Premiums EAs impose significant risk on investors and the release of the earnings information can cause large price revisions in equity values (i.e., jumps in asset prices). Indeed, numerous studies in accounting and finance establish that EAs convey valuation-relevant news about the announcing firm and, before the release of the report, implied volatilities tend to rise in the equity option market (e.g., Neururer et al., 2016). EAs may also convey news about overall market and economic conditions, imposing undiversifiable announcement risk on investors (Savor and Wilson, 2016). Thus, investors may demand extra compensation for bearing risk across the announcement period. Moreover, EAs may also impose additional idiosyncratic risks if investors do not hold well-diversified portfolios. The first study to document that, on average, stock prices increase around their EADs is Beaver (1968). Subsequently, several other studies have documented this same basic fact including Chari et al. (1988) and Ball and Kothari (1991). These studies find the EA premium is not explained by factors such as firm size, book-to-market ratios, and return momentum. The results collectively suggest that investors are compensated for bearing risk across the announcement period. (2019) find that the average IV for their sample is 8.2% while the actual realized announcement date volatility is only 7.4% suggesting that there is a large volatility premium in the options market around EADs. Our study is related to all these prior papers as we examine the returns to securities around EADs. However, our main question of interest in this paper is the presence of skewness and its corresponding pricing around EAs. Our proxy for skewness is the DNRR; we construct the DNRRs to be explicitly hedged against small movements in both expected volatility and stock price movements and, thus, the position is not initially exposed to the risks already explored in prior studies. Instead, the position is exposed to rare but large negative or positive stock price movements, and consequently, our results also speak to the premium embedded in equity options to hedge and trade skew risk. Delta-Neutral Risk Reversals and Skew Risk Premiums The two options spread positions that we investigate in this paper are risk reversals and straddles. First, a straddle involves the purchase or sale of both a put and call option at the same time with the same expiration date with the same strike price. The strike price chosen will typically be close to the current stock or forward price. Thus, because the put option will have roughly the opposite negative delta of the call option’s positive delta, the position will be insensitive to the direction of the changes in the stock price. Instead, because the position is long (short) both the call and the put, an investor is initially indifferent to the actual direction of the stock price but, instead, profits if the stock moves aggressively (does not move) in either direction. Consequently, traders consider straddle positions to be bets or hedges on stock volatility. text: A risk reversal, on the other hand, is the purchase of an OTM put and the sale of an OTM call with the same expiration. This combination will result in a large directional (delta) position that an investor can hedge with a long position in the stock. Note that if the purchase and sale quantities are done in the correct amounts in the option and equity markets, the DNRR is initially insensitive to small movements for both stock price and volatility. Stated differently, the position is initially hedged against both stock and volatility risk. We select the options with the nearest expiration date relative to the EAD between ten and forty calendar days inclusive. Next, we select a put and a call that have absolute deltas between 0.40 and 0.10 (i.e., OTM options). If multiple options meet these criteria, we choose a put and a call with an absolute delta nearest to 0.25. For some of our tests, we also control for the returns to at-the-money (ATM) straddles. text: Systematic and Idiosyncratic Risk We next test if systematic versus idiosyncratic risk proxies help to explain the cross- section of skew risk premiums on EADs. Firms with higher systematic risk impose more market-related risk on investors with their disclosures because their information is more relevant to the updating of other firms’ values and their information provides more information about the overall economy. text: In this study, we examine the premiums to skew risk around quarterly EADs embedded in equity option prices. EAs represent large information disclosure events and they can change stock prices dramatically. In addition, prior research finds that realized stock returns are more negatively skewed on EADs relative to non-EADs. However, some theoretical option pricing models suggest that the predictable EA jumps should not affect the relative pricing of OTM puts to calls. To operationalize skew risk premiums, we study the returns to DNRRs. Our findings suggest that skew premiums are significant and elevated around EAs. In particular, DNRRs earn significantly lower returns for firms with negative implied skewness. However, we also present evidence that DNRRs returns are higher on EADs when the firms have positive implied skew. These results hold when we control for the contemporaneous returns to ATM straddles suggesting that the documented skew premiums are not subsumed by variance risk premiums. We also find that IV skews are highly predictive of DRNN returns and DNRR return sensitivity to implied skews is higher on EADs. We also present evidence that DNRR returns are more extreme for firms with high total variance. However, our results indicate the source of the return variance, be it systematic or idiosyncratic variance, is not important for explaining the cross-section of DNRR returns on EADs. Finally, we find that EA saliency, EA report timing, and firms’ record of meeting earnings targets help explain the cross-section of EAD DNRR returns.
